title: 110_s2020
content: The Act titled "Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2007" expands its scope to include coral conservation, amending the previous Tropical Forest Conservation Act of 1998. This expansion aims to protect both forests and coral reefs. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reefs and coastal marine ecosystems in its protection scope. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reefs and coastal marine ecosystems in its protection scope by making specific changes to the text. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reefs by adding new definitions for coral species in the phylum Cnidaria. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reefs, defining terms such as coral reef, associated coastal marine ecosystem, and coral species in the phylum Cnidaria. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to change the name of the facility from "Tropical Forest Facility" to "Conservation Facility". This change is reflected in definitions and references throughout the Act. Eligibility for benefits is also addressed. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reef conservation in eligibility for benefits. Additionally, the United States government representation on oversight bodies for grants from debt-for-nature swaps and debt-buybacks is addressed. Section 808(a)(5) of the Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to allow individuals appointed by the United States Government to serve on the administering body overseeing grants from debt-for-nature swaps or debt buy-backs. This includes situations where the United States is not a party to the agreement between the purchaser and the beneficiary country. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to rename agreements and eliminate the requirement to consult with the Enterprise for the Americas Board. The role of beneficiary countries is also revised. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to prioritize projects that enhance governance and management of tropical forests and coral reefs. Grants over $250,000 require approval from the US and beneficiary country governments. Technical amendments are also made. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to include coral reefs and associated coastal marine ecosystems. Amendments also specify criteria for individuals dependent on tropical forests or coral reefs. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to rename the fund to "conservation fund" and the agreement to "conservation agreement." Definitions in the Act are also amended to reflect these changes. The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to rename the fund to "conservation fund" in various sections of the Act. SEC. 9 repeals the authority of the Enterprise for the Americas Board to carry out activities under the Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007. SEC. 10 makes changes to the due dates of annual reports to Congress. SEC. 10 amends the Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 by changing the due dates of annual reports to Congress to April 15 and updating terminology. Subsection (b) is removed. SEC. 11 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 regarding the International Monetary Fund criterion for country eligibility. It removes certain language and updates requirements for eligibility. SEC. 12 authorizes new appropriations for debt reduction and expenses related to audit, evaluation, monitoring, and administration. Section 806 of the Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007 is amended to allocate specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010. Additionally, $300,000 is authorized for audits, evaluations, monitoring, and administration of programs under this act. The title is amended to reflect these changes. The bill aims to reauthorize the Tropical Forest Conservation Act of 1998 through fiscal year 2010, renaming it as the Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act of 2007. It also allocates specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010, with $300,000 authorized for audits, evaluations, monitoring, and administration.
